content: How can I help you today?

I’m here because, honestly, my wife pushed me to do this. Things have been tough at home, and I’m struggling to figure out how to fix it. I’m not sure how much this will help, but I guess I’m willing to talk.

It sounds like things have been challenging for you at home, and it's brought you here today. It's a big step to be open to talking, and it shows your willingness to try something, even if you're not quite sure where it will lead. What’s been feeling the most difficult for you lately?

It's really hard to focus on anything because of our situation at home. My son is having behavioral challenges, and no matter what we try, we don’t seem to be helping him. It's affecting everything—my marriage, my work, and even my ability to enjoy anything. I feel like I’m failing as a dad and a husband.

That sounds incredibly overwhelming—trying so hard to help your son while feeling like it's taking a toll on so many areas of your life. It’s clear how deeply you care about your family and want things to get better for everyone. What’s been standing out to you the most about how this has been affecting you personally?

I just feel drained all the time, emotionally and mentally. I can't stop worrying about my son and whether we're doing enough for him, and at the same time, my wife and I are arguing more. It feels like I'm stuck, and no matter what I do, things aren't improving.

It’s exhausting to carry so much worry and feel like nothing is working, especially when it’s affecting your relationships and your own well-being. You're balancing a lot right now, and it sounds like you're trying so hard because you want the best for your son and your family. What do you think has made things feel so stuck for you?

I think it's just that nothing seems to work. We’ve tried different things with my son—setting boundaries, rewarding good behavior, even being more patient—but nothing seems to make a lasting difference. And with my wife, it's hard to even talk about it without it turning into another argument. It feels like we’re both just running out of energy and ideas.

It sounds like you and your wife have been putting in a lot of effort to support your son, and yet it feels discouraging when you don't see lasting improvements. On top of that, the strain on your relationship makes it harder to feel united and supported. It’s a lot to carry. What keeps you going, even during moments when it feels this heavy?

I think what keeps me going is that I really want to help my son and keep my family together. I don’t want to give up on any of them. It’s just hard to see a clear path forward when everything feels so overwhelming right now.

Your commitment to your son and your family really shines through, even in the midst of all this overwhelm. Wanting to hold things together and not give up speaks volumes about your dedication and love for them. It’s natural to feel lost when the way forward isn’t clear. What do you think would help you feel just a little more clarity or hope right now?

Honestly, I don’t know. Maybe just… knowing what to do next or having some kind of plan. Right now, it feels like I’m constantly reacting, and nothing is changing. I guess having someone to guide us, or even a glimmer of progress, would make it feel less hopeless.

It sounds like having some guidance or seeing even a small sign of progress could make a huge difference for you. Feeling like you're always reacting must be so draining, and maybe having a clearer direction would take some of that weight off. This might be a tough question, but are there times when things have felt even a little bit better, even for a moment?

I can’t think of many moments lately. Maybe a few times when my son was calm, and we were able to just sit and watch TV together—it reminded me of how things used to be. But those times are rare, and they don’t last long before everything feels chaotic again.

Those moments, even if rare, hold so much meaning. It sounds like they give you a glimpse of what you’re hoping to create more of—peaceful, connected times with your son. Even though the chaos tends to return, those brief calm moments show that there’s still potential for connection amidst the challenges. What do those moments mean to you?

They mean everything, honestly. They remind me that my son is still in there somewhere, and those peaceful moments are what I want more of—for him, for me, and for our family. It’s just hard to hold onto that feeling when the chaos keeps coming back.

Those moments feel like a reflection of what you deeply value—your son's well-being, your connection with him, and the vision of a calmer, more united family. It’s understandable that, when chaos returns, it can feel like those moments slip away. But the fact that they happen, even now, suggests that change might still be possible. What do you think it would take to try building more of those peaceful moments, even in small ways?

It’s hard to say. Maybe more patience, which I feel like I’m running out of, or some new approach that actually works. I’m not sure where to even start, though. It feels like we’ve already tried so much.

It’s really tough when it feels like you’ve already given so much and still feel stuck. Your desire to find a way forward shows just how much this matters to you, even when you’re feeling drained. Would it feel helpful to explore where you might find new options or support to work through this together?
I think that might be helpful, but I honestly don’t know where to look or who to turn to. The idea of starting from scratch or reaching out for more help feels kind of overwhelming.

Taking that first step to seek support can feel daunting, especially when you're already carrying so much. It makes sense that it feels overwhelming. What might make the idea of reaching out feel a bit more manageable for you?
